translation.en: [Barack Obama] So let's look at the statistics.
The United States is home to 5% of the world's population...
but 25% of the world's prisoners.
Think about that.
[Van Jones] A little country with 5% of the world's population
having 25% of the world's prisoners?
One out of four?
One out of four human beings with their hands on bars, shackled,
translation.ko: 전 세계 수감자 중에서 넷 중 하나는

translation.en: in the world are locked up here, in the land of the free.
We had a prison population of 300,000 in 1972.
Today, we have a prison population of 2.3 million.
The United States now has the highest rate of incarceration in the world.
translation.ko: 미국의 죄수 수감률은 전 세계에서 가장 높습니다

translation.en: So, you see, now suddenly they're in an awakening that,
"Oh, perhaps we need to downsize our prison system.
translation.ko: 감옥 체계의 규모를 줄여야 할 수도 있겠다고요

translation.en: It's gotten too expensive. It's gotten out of hand."
translation.ko: 비용이 너무 많이 들어서 감당 못 할 지경이니까요

translation.en: Um, but the very folks who often express so much concern,
uh, about the cost and the expanse of the system
are often very unwilling to talk in any serious way
translation.ko: 지금까지 하던 방식의 결점을 고치는 일엔

translation.en: about remedying the harm that has been done.
History is not just stuff that happens by accident.
We are the products of the history that our ancestors chose, if we're white.
translation.ko: 우리는 조상이 정한 역사의 산물입니다 백인이라면요

translation.en: If we are black, we are products of the history that our ancestors
translation.ko: 흑인이라면 필시 조상이 정한 게 아닌

translation.en: most likely did not choose.
Yet here we all are together, the products of that set of choices.
translation.ko: 그러한 선택이 모여 지금의 우리를 만들었고

translation.en: And we have to understand that in order to escape from it.
translation.ko: 우린 그걸 이해해야 여기서 벗어날 수 있습니다

translation.en: The 13th Amendment to the Constitution
makes it unconstitutional for someone to be held as a slave.
translation.ko: 노예 제도는 위헌이 됐습니다 "노예제 폐지 해방, 자유"

translation.en: In other words, it grants freedom...
to all Americans.
There are exceptions, including criminals.
[Khalil G. Muhammad] There's a clause, a loophole.
translation.ko: 한 조항이 있습니다 법의 맹점이죠 "범죄의 처벌은 예외로 한다"

translation.en: [Kevin Gannon] If you have that in the structure, in this constitutional language,
translation.ko: 법 조항에 이런 문구가 들어 있다면

translation.en: then it's there to be used as a tool
for whichever purposes one wants to use it.
[Cobb] One of the things to bear in mind is that
when we think about slavery, it was an economic system.
And the demise of slavery at the end of the Civil War
left the Southern economy in tatters. Uh, and so this presented a big question.
translation.ko: 남부 경제가 무너졌다는 겁니다 그리고 그 사실은 큰 문제를 불러왔습니다

translation.en: There are four million people who were formerly property,
and they were formerly kind of the integral part
of the economic production system in the South.
And now those people are free.
And so what do you do with these people?
How do you rebuild your economy?
The 13th Amendment loophole was immediately exploited.
translation.ko: 미국 수정헌법 제13조의 맹점이 즉시 악용됐습니다

translation.en: After the Civil War, African Americans were arrested en masse.
It was our nation's first prison boom.
[Gannon] You were basically a slave again. The 13th Amendment says that
translation.ko: 다시 노예로 전락한 셈이었죠 미국 수정헌법 제13조에 따르면

translation.en: "Except for criminals, everybody else is free."
Well, now if you're criminalized, that doesn't apply to you.
[Michelle Alexander] They were arrested for extremely minor crimes,
like loitering or vagrancy.
And they had to provide labor
to rebuild the economy of the South after the Civil War.
translation.ko: 남부 경제 재건에 노동력을 제공해야 했습니다

translation.en: [Cobb] What you got after that was a rapid transition
translation.ko: 다음으론 흑인 범죄에 대한 그릇된 믿음이

translation.en: to a kind of mythology of black criminality.
Go back and, you know, read the rhetoric that people used then.
They would say that the Negro was out of control,
that there's a threat of violence to white women.
So the same sort of image that we had of Uncle Remus
and these genial, kind of, black figures
was replaced by this rapacious, uh, menacing, Negro male evil
translation.ko: 탐욕스러운 이미지로 바뀌었죠 세상에서 사라져야 할

translation.en: that had to be banished.
[Gannon] Birth of a Nation was
just a profoundly important cultural event.
[Muhammad] It's the first major blockbuster film,
hailed for both its artistic achievement and for its political commentary.
translation.ko: 뛰어난 예술성과 정치적 해석으로 환호를 받았어요

translation.en: And when it was released, it had this rapturous response.
You know, there were lines everywhere that it was being shown.
Birth of a Nation confirmed the story
translation.ko: "국가의 탄생에 감격한 대중" '국가의 탄생'은 백인들이 말하고 싶던

translation.en: that many whites wanted to tell about the Civil War and its aftermath.
To erase defeat and to take out of it sort of a martyrdom.
Woodrow Wilson, the sitting president, had a private screening
translation.ko: 당시 대통령이던 우드로 윌슨은 백악관에서 '국가의 탄생'을 단독 상영했고

translation.en: of it in the White House. He calls it, "History written with lightning."
translation.ko: 백악관에서 '국가의 탄생'을 단독 상영했고 '빛으로 쓴 역사'라고 칭송했습니다

translation.en: And every image you see of a black person is a demeaned, animal-like image.
translation.ko: 영화에 나타나는 흑인을 전부 짐승처럼 비하했어요

translation.en: Cannibalistic, animalistic.
The image of the African American male.
[Cobb] There's a famous scene where a woman throws herself off a cliff
translation.ko: 여자가 흑인에게 강간당하느니 절벽에서 몸을 던져 버리는

translation.en: rather than be raped by a black male criminal.
In the film, you see black people being a threat to white women.
translation.ko: 영화에서 흑인은 백인 여자에게 위험한 존재죠

translation.en: All the myths of black men as rapists was ultimately stemmed by the reality
translation.ko: 흑인 남자는 전부 강간범이라는 믿음이 생겨났습니다 백인인 정치 지배층과 사업가들에게

translation.en: that the white political elite and the business establishment
translation.ko: 백인인 정치 지배층과 사업가들에게 흑인 일꾼이 필요했다는 현실 때문에요

translation.en: needed black bodies working.
[Cobb] What we overlook about Birth of a Nation
is that it was also a tremendously accurate prediction
of the way in which race would operate in the United States.
[Cobb] Birth of a Nation was almost directly responsible
for the rebirth of the Ku Klux Klan.
It had received this romantic, glowing, heroic portrait.
The Klan never had the ritual of burning the cross.
That was something that D.W. Griffith came up with
because he thought that it was a great cinematic image.
So it was literally an instance of life imitating art.
translation.ko: 말 그대로 삶이 예술을 흉내 냈죠

translation.en: The ripples emanate far out
from just the simple fact that it's a movie
in the early motion picture age.
[Cobb] With the tremendous burst of popularity
that the Ku Klux Klan had as a result of Birth of a Nation
came another wave of terrorism.
[Stevenson] We had lynchings between Reconstruction and World War II.
Thousands of African Americans murdered by mobs
translation.ko: 무수히 많은 흑인이 범죄자일 거란 오해로

translation.en: under the idea that they had done something criminal.
[reporter] At the National Democratic Convention in New York in 1924,
translation.ko: "어제 한 명 린치당함" 1924년 뉴욕 민주당 전당 대회에서

translation.en: it is estimated that at least 350 delegates were Klansmen.
[Stevenson] The demographic geography of this country was shaped by that era.
translation.ko: 지금의 인구 분포가 그 시대에 만들어졌어요

translation.en: Now we have African Americans in Los Angeles,
in Oakland, and Chicago, and Cleveland, Detroit, Boston, New York.
translation.ko: LA, 오클랜드, 시카고 클리블랜드, 디트로이트 보스턴, 뉴욕에 흑인들이 살고 있는데

translation.en: And very few people appreciate that the African Americans in those communities
translation.ko: 그곳에 사는 흑인들이 일자리를 찾아 이주한 게 아니라

translation.en: did not go there as immigrants looking for new economic opportunities.
translation.ko: 일자리를 찾아 이주한 게 아니라 위협을 피해 도망왔다는 사실을

translation.en: They went there as refugees from terror.
We didn't just land in Oakland, in LA, in Compton,
in Harlem, in Brownsville in 2015.
translation.ko: 할렘, 브라운스빌에 그냥 정착한 게 아니에요

translation.en: This is generational... generational trauma.
[reporter] The letters "KKK" were carved with a penknife
on the chest and stomach of this man in Houston, Texas,
after he had been hanged by his knees from an oak tree and flogged with a chain.
translation.ko: 주머니칼로 가슴과 배에 KKK란 글자가 새겨지고 사슬로 채찍질 당했습니다 "3천 명이 검둥이를 불태울 것"

translation.en: The Chicago Negro boy, Emmett Till, is alleged
translation.ko: 시카고의 검둥이, 에멧 틸은 로이 브라이언트의 아름다운 아내에게

translation.en: to have paid unwelcome attention to Roy Bryant's most attractive wife.
translation.ko: 로이 브라이언트의 아름다운 아내에게 불쾌한 관심을 보였다고 합니다

translation.en: [Stevenson] And then when it became unacceptable
to engage in that kind of open terrorism,
then it shifted to something more legal.
Segregation. Jim Crow.
translation.ko: "차별이여, 영원하여라" 흑백 분리 법인 짐 크로입니다

translation.en: [Alexander] Laws were passed that relegated African Americans
to a permanent second-class status.
translation.ko: 법안이 통과했어요 "앨라배마에서 30만이 넘는 흑인이 투표 거부당하다"

translation.en: These things really begin to live out the prophecy that Griffith was making
translation.ko: 이런 일들이 정말로 실현되기 시작했어요 그리피스가 인종 차별에 대해 묘사했던 대로요

translation.en: about the way that race operates.
translation.ko: 그리피스가 인종 차별에 대해 묘사했던 대로요 "젤라니 콥 미국 흑인학 교수"

translation.en: And this fear of crime is central to all of this.
Every time you saw a sign that said "white and colored,"
every time you had to deal with the indignation
of being told you can't go through the front door.
Every day you weren't allowed to vote,
translation.ko: "브라이언 스티븐슨 변호사 겸 작가" 투표나 학교에 가는 것도 허락되지 않았어요

translation.en: weren't allowed to go to school,
translation.ko: 투표나 학교에 가는 것도 허락되지 않았어요

translation.en: you were bearing a burden that was injurious.
translation.ko: 투표나 학교에 가는 것도 허락되지 않았어요 그건 부당한 짐이었어요

translation.en: [Alexander] Civil rights activists began to see the necessity
of building not just a civil rights movement,
but a human rights movement.
[Martin Luther King Jr.] And I think we should start now preparing for the inevitable. [crowd] Yeah!
[King] And let us, when that moment comes...
translation.ko: 그리고 마침내 그 순간이 왔을 때

translation.en: go into the situations that we confront
with a great deal of dignity, sanity and reasonableness.
translation.ko: 우리가 마주한 상황에 들어가야 합니다 커다란 존엄성과 온전함과 합당함으로요

translation.en: [KKK member] They want to throw white children and colored children
into the melting pot of integration,
through out of which will come a conglomerated,
mulatto, mongrel class of people.
Both races will be destroyed in such a movement.
translation.ko: 그런 흐름 속에선 모두 말살되고 맙니다

translation.en: [reporter 1] We just got a report here on this end that the students are in.
[reporter 2] Negroes were trying to integrate the bathing beaches.
And the Florida Advisory Committee to the US Civil Rights Commission
warned that the city was becoming a racial superbomb with a short fuse.
translation.ko: 이 도시가 금세 터져버릴 인종 간의 폭탄이 될 거로 경고했습니다

translation.en: [Alexander] Civil rights activists began to be portrayed in the media
and among, you know, many politicians as criminals.
People who are deliberately violating the law,
segregation laws that existed in the South.
[King] For years now, I have heard the word "wait."
It rings in the ear of every Negro with piercing familiarity.
This wait has almost always meant never.
Justice too long delayed is justice denied.
translation.ko: 너무 오래 지연된 정의는 정의가 아닙니다

translation.en: I think that one of the most brilliant tactics of the civil rights movement
was its transformation of the notion of criminality.
Because for the first time, being arrested was a noble thing.
translation.ko: 처음으로 체포되는 게 숭고한 것이 됐으니까요 "헨리 루이스 게이츠 하버드대 역사학 교수"

translation.en: Being arrested by white people was your worst nightmare.
Still is, uh, for many African Americans.
So what'd they do?
They voluntarily defined a movement around getting arrested.
translation.ko: 그래서 그들은 자진해서 주변에 운동임을 알리고 체포되러 갔어요

translation.en: They turned it on its head.
[Cobb] If you looked at the history
of black people's various struggles in this country,
translation.ko: 이 나라에서 흑인들이 벌인 다양한 투쟁의 역사 속에서

translation.en: the connecting theme is the attempt to be understood
translation.ko: 계속 이어져 온 주제는 완전한 인간으로

translation.en: as full, complicated human beings.
We are something other than this, uh, visceral image of criminality
translation.ko: "나는 인간이다" 우리는 본능밖에 모르고 주변 사람들에게

translation.en: and menace and threat to which people associate with us.
We're willing to be beaten for democracy, and you misuse democracy in the street.
translation.ko: 민주주의를 위해서 기꺼이 얻어맞을 수 있어요 당신들은 민주주의를 오용하고 있어요

translation.en: Let us lay aside irrelevant differences...
and make our nation whole.
[Gates] The Civil Rights Act and the Voting Rights Act said,
"Finally, we admit it.
Though slavery ended in December 1865...
we took away these people's rights, and now we're gonna fix it."
translation.ko: 그들의 권리를 빼앗았다가 이제 그걸 바로잡게 됐어요

translation.en: [Marc Mauer] For the first time,
you know, promise of equal justice becomes at least a possibility.
translation.ko: 처음으로 평등한 정의가 실현될 가능성을 약속받았어요

translation.en: Their cause must be our cause, too.
[Alexander] Unfortunately, at the very same time
that the civil rights movement was gaining steam,
translation.ko: 힘을 얻기 시작한 바로 그 시기에

translation.en: crime rates were beginning to rise in this country.
Crime was increasing in the baby boom generation
that had emerged immediately after World War II.
translation.ko: "존 헤이건 사회학, 법학 교수" 베이비붐 세대는

translation.en: Now they were adults.
So, just through sheer demographic change, we had an increase in the amount of crime.
translation.ko: 인구 통계학상의 급격한 변화로 범죄의 횟수가 늘어난 거죠

translation.en: ...and became very easy for politicians then to say,
um, that the civil rights movement itself was contributing to rising crime rates,
translation.ko: 시민권 운동으로 "미셸 알렉산더 교육가 겸 작가" 범죄율이 높아졌으니까

translation.en: and that if we were to give the Negroes their freedom, um,
then we would be repaid, as a nation, with crime.
[Stevenson] The prison population in the United States was largely flat
throughout most of the 20th century.
It didn't go up a lot. It didn't come down a lot.
But that changed in the 1970s.
And in the 1970s, we began an era
which has been defined by this term, "mass incarceration."
This is a nation of laws, and as Abraham Lincoln has said,
"No one is above the law. No one is below the law."
translation.ko: 누구도 법 위에 있거나 아래에 있지 않습니다

translation.en: And we're going to enforce the law
and Americans should remember that, if we're going to have law and order.
translation.ko: 법질서 확립을 위해 국민은 이 말을 기억해야 합니다 "법과 질서"

translation.en: [Richard Nixon] Each moment in history is a fleeting time, precious and unique.
translation.ko: 역사의 매 순간은 쏜살같고 귀중하고 특별하지만

translation.en: But some stand out as moments of beginning...
in which courses are set that shape decades or centuries.
translation.ko: 수십, 수백 년에 걸쳐 그 형태가 나타나기도 합니다 "1970년 수감자 수 357,292명"

translation.en: This can be such a moment.
It's with the Nixon era, and the law and order period
translation.ko: 닉슨 시대가 되면서 법질서의 시대가 왔어요 "안젤라 데이비스 UC산타크루즈대 명예 교수"

translation.en: when crime begins to stand in for race.
If there is one area where the word "war" is appropriate,
it is in the fight against crime.
Part of what he talked about was a war on crime.
But that was one of those code words,
translation.ko: 그건 일종의 암호예요 "제임스 킬고어 과거 투옥됐던 작가"

translation.en: what we might call "dog-whistle politics" now, which really was referring to
translation.ko: 소위 편 가르기식 정치 언어로 사실 다른 걸 뜻해요

translation.en: the black political movements of the day, Black Power, Black Panthers,
translation.ko: 당시의 흑인 정치 운동 블랙파워, 블랙팬서

translation.en: the antiwar movement,
the movements for women's and gay liberation at that time,
translation.ko: 여성 해방 운동과 동성애자 해방 운동을요

translation.en: which Nixon felt compelled to fight back against.
Once the federal government, through the FBI, moves into an area,
translation.ko: 연방 정부가 FBI를 통해 한 지역으로 움직이면

translation.en: this should be warning to those who engage in these acts
translation.ko: 범죄에 연루된 자들에게 경고가 될 거고

translation.en: that they eventually are going to be apprehended.
[Cobb] There's this outcry for law and order.
And Nixon becomes the person who articulates that perfectly.
[Nixon] There can be no progress in America without respect for law.
Many people felt like, uh, we were losing control.
translation.ko: 많은 이들이 우리가 통제력을 잃었다고 느꼈어요

translation.en: [Nixon] We need total war in the United States
against the evils, uh, that we see in our cities.
Federal spending for local law enforcement will double.
translation.ko: 연방 정부는 지방 경찰력을 두 배로 늘릴 겁니다

translation.en: Time is running out for the merchants
of crime and corruption in American society.
The wave of crime is not going to be the wave of the future
in the United States of America.
We must wage what I have called "total war"
translation.ko: 우린 미국 최대 공공의 적과 벌이는 이 전쟁에서

translation.en: against public enemy number one in the United States,
translation.ko: 우린 미국 최대 공공의 적과 벌이는 이 전쟁에서 계속 싸워야 합니다

translation.en: the problem of dangerous drugs.
"A war on drugs."
And that utterance gave birth to this era,
translation.ko: 그 발언으로 마약 중독과 약물 의존 문제를

translation.en: where we decided to deal with drug addiction and drug dependency
as a crime issue rather than a health issue.
translation.ko: 마약을 건강이 아닌 범죄 문제로 취급했죠

translation.en: Hundreds of thousands of people
were sent to jails and prisons for simple possession of marijuana,
for low-level offenses.
America's public enemy number one in the United States is drug abuse.
In order to fight and defeat this enemy,
it is necessary to wage a new, all-out offensive.
This call for law and order becomes integral to something that
translation.ko: 법질서에 대한 이러한 요구는 필수 불가결한 요소였고

translation.en: comes to be known as the Southern strategy.
translation.ko: 이는 차후 남부 전략으로 불립니다 "남부 전략"

translation.en: Nixon begins to recruit Southern whites, formerly staunch Democrats,
translation.ko: 닉슨은 남부 백인들을 설득하기 시작하고 거만했던 과거 민주당원을 공화당으로 끌어들였습니다

translation.en: into the Republican fold.
translation.ko: 거만했던 과거 민주당원을 공화당으로 끌어들였습니다 "공화당에 투표를"

translation.ko: 우리가 그런 죄를 만들고 아이들에게 알려줬어요

translation.en: "That's a rapist. That's a murderer.
That's a robber. That's a sex offender.

And through that lens, it becomes so much easier

translation.en: to accept that they're guilty and that they should go to prison.
The objective reality is... that virtually no one who is white

translation.en: So you have then educated a public, deliberately, over years, over decades,

translation.en: to believe that black men in particular, and black people in general,

I want to be clear,

Black people also believe this and are terrified of our own selves.

translation.en: You want to go back to the days of military weakness,

translation.en: [man] Leadership that's on your side. Michael Dukakis for president.

translation.en: [Kilgore] That Dukakis had a double-digit lead over Bush
translation.ko: 듀카키스는 부시에 두 자릿수 지지율로 앞섰어요

A very racially, um...

translation.ko: 민주당원들은 그가 흑인인 걸 알리고 싶었어요

It was not his name,

translation.en: Liberals that announced that it was mean to pick on a murderer and a rapist

"I will be the savior and protector of the white population."
translation.ko: 제가 백인의 구세주이자 보호자가 될 겁니다

translation.en: Never minding the fact that the history of interracial rape in this country,

translation.ko: 사실은 백인의 흑인 여성 강간이 흑인의 백인 여성 강간보다

translation.en: than of black men against white women.
Patsey.
[Cobb] This idea that had such great artistic utility

The way that we appeal to voters' sense of fear and anxiety in our nation

translation.en: [announcer] A new generation of Democrats, Bill Clinton and Al Gore.

They've sent a strong signal to criminals by supporting the death penalty.

It became virtually impossible

We'd consistently had, "Squishy, soft liberal won't protect you.

translation.en: I will faithfully execute the Office of President of the United States.

[Mauer] Polly Klaas, abducted from her bedroom at home and ultimately killed,

translation.en: which led to the California "three strikes and you're out" law.
When you commit a third violent crime,

Three strikes and you are out.
A person's convicted of their third felony,

[reporter] So many third-strike defendants awaiting trial,

It's in line with many other policies we've created,
translation.ko: 그 제도는 우리 정책들과 같은 선상에 있었어요

translation.en: particularly mandatory minimums.
"Mandatory sentencing." We said we were no longer going to let judges
translation.ko: 최소 실형을 선고할 때 판사는 이제 범죄 환경을 고려하지 않습니다

[Martin] Truth in Sentencing. You're sentenced to an amount of time.

translation.en: The public wants to be confident
that you're gonna do just about every bit of that time.
We've done away with parole.
translation.ko: 가석방을 없앴어요 "데이비드 킨 전 미국 보수연합 회장"

translation.en: We had parole in this country

translation.en: That omnibus crime bill was responsible

And beyond that, it provided all kinds of money and perverse incentives
translation.ko: 그 이후로 지금은 남용으로 간주하는 뒤틀린 법 집행 장려책에

translation.en: for law enforcement to do a lot of the things

translation.en: that we nowadays consider to be abusive.
It will be used to build prisons to keep 100,000 violent criminals off the street.

translation.en: [Stevenson] Not only does he increase funding to states to build prisons

translation.en: to lock up as many people involved in drug crimes,

Crime has been a hot political issue used too often to divide us.
translation.ko: 범죄는 우리를 분열시키려고 빈번하게 이용된 정치 이슈입니다

translation.en: What President Clinton did in 1994
translation.ko: 클린턴 대통령이 1994년 시행한 정책은 "크레이그 디로슈 과거 투옥됐던 운동가"

translation.en: is actually far more harmful than his predecessors

translation.ko: 모든 경찰 조직을 군대화하고 특공대를 조직했죠

translation.en: There were longer sentences.
And most of these people are in prison under state law,

translation.en: but the federal law set a trend.
And that was overdone. We were wrong about that.
Well, I think it's important that President Clinton, um, acknowledges
translation.ko: 클린턴 대통령과 우리가 바라던 대로 되지 않았단 사실을 그가 시인한다는 게

translation.en: that things didn't turn out exactly as he and all of us would've wished.
translation.ko: 되지 않았단 사실을 그가 시인한다는 게 중요하다고 생각해요

translation.en: I'm happy that he realizes the error of his ways.
I think he knew back then that it wasn't good policy, I'll be honest.
translation.ko: 좋은 정책이 아닌 건 그때도 알았을 거예요

translation.en: Back then, there was an outcry over the rising crime rate.
translation.ko: 그땐 치솟는 범죄율로 강력한 대응을 기대했어요

translation.en: And people from all communities were asking that action be taken.
Now, my husband said at the NAACP last summer
translation.ko: 지난여름 제 남편이 미국 흑인 지위 향상 협회에서

translation.en: that it solved some problems, but it created other problems,
translation.ko: 그 정책으로 어떤 문제는 해결했지만 다른 문제를 일으켰다고 했죠 동의합니다

translation.en: and I agree.
I'm glad to see that he is apologetic,
but I think he has to take responsibility and accountability for that,
translation.ko: 그에 따른 책임과 의무를 져야 해요

translation.en: and so does Hillary,
because she supported it, then and up until recently.
translation.ko: 힐러리도요 그때 이후 최근까지도 그 정책을 지원했으니까요

translation.en: [reporter] Bill Clinton faced off against a group of Black Lives Matter protestors
translation.ko: 빌 클린턴이 범죄 법안에 대해 '흑인의 생명도 소중하다'고

translation.en: protesting a 1994 crime bill
that they say led to a surge in the imprisonment of black people.
I don't know how you would characterize
the gang leaders who got 13-year-old kids hopped up on crack
translation.ko: 마약에 취한 13짜리 꼬마를 거리로 내보내 다른 흑인 아이를 죽이게 한 갱단 두목을

translation.en: and sent 'em out onto the street to murder other African American children.
translation.ko: 다른 흑인 아이를 죽이게 한 갱단 두목을 어떻게 생각하는지 궁금하군요

translation.en: Maybe you thought they were good citizens. She didn't.
-She didn't! -[crowd cheering]
You are defending the people who kill the lives you say matter.
translation.ko: 당신은 소중한 흑인의 생명을 앗아간 자를 옹호하고 있어요

translation.en: Tell the truth.
We can't ignore the reality of force here.
The policies that Bill Clinton put forward,
you know, mandatory minimums, three strikes...
Those were a use of political force.
They forced millions of people,
who would not otherwise be in prison today, into prison.
They forced families to be broken.
They forced children to live without their parents.
That's what happened.
[Jones] Why?
We shouldn't ask, "Why is Bill Clinton so strong?"
translation.ko: 빌 클린턴이 왜 그렇게 강했는지 물어선 안 돼요

translation.en: We should ask, "Why is the black community so weak
in our inability to defend ourselves?"
Let's not forget how many martyrs we put in the ground in the '60s and '70s.
translation.ko: 60-70년대 수많은 순교자가 땅에 묻혔단 걸 잊지 말아요

translation.en: Let's not forget how many of our leaders had to leave the country or are in prison.
translation.ko: 수많은 우리의 지도자가 나라를 떠나거나 구금됐단 걸 잊지 말아요

translation.en: You stripped out a whole generation of leadership.
You ran them out the country, you put them in prison,
you put them in... in cemeteries.
translation.ko: 외국으로 추방하고 감옥에 집어넣고 묘지에 묻어버렸어요

translation.en: And then you unleash this blitzkrieg,
and we don't have the ability to defend ourselves.
You can tell the story of white leadership in America
and never mention the FBI one time.
translation.ko: 백인 지도자에 대해 얘기할 순 있습니다

translation.en: You can't tell the story of black leadership, not one,
without having to deal with the full weight

translation.ko: 형사 사법 제도의 책임을 다루지 않고선 힘듭니다

translation.en: I'm tired of living every day under the threat of death.
I have no martyr complex.
I want to live as long as anybody in this building tonight.
translation.ko: 이곳에 모인 여러분처럼 오래 살고 싶죠

translation.en: [Jones] Dr. King, people forget, was not this beloved figure
translation.ko: 사람들은 잊었지만, 킹 박사는 모두가 받침대에 올려놓고 싶어 하는

translation.en: that everybody wants to put on a pedestal.
Uh, he was considered one of the most dangerous people in America
translation.ko: FBI 국장은 킹을 미국에서 가장 위험한

translation.en: by the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigations.
translation.ko: 주의할 인물로 지목했죠 "FBI 국장 마틴 루서 킹을 '최악의 거짓말쟁이'라 불러"

translation.en: Don't tell me that Dr. King has no relevance

They dealing with little cops. He was dealing with the top cop.
translation.ko: 그들은 경찰 몇 명이지만 킹은 우두머리를 상대했어요

translation.en: [Malcolm X] We were brought here against our will.
We were not brought here to be made citizens.
We were not brought here to enjoy the, uh, constitutional gifts

translation.en: that they speak so beautifully about.

He may have had as many police

translation.ko: 그는 일반 수행단만큼이나 많은 경찰을 비밀리에 측근으로 두게 했을 겁니다

translation.en: So afraid of black dissent.
FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover today asserted that the Black Panthers
translation.ko: FBI 국장 존 에드거 후버는 블랙팬서를

[Gates] J. Edgar Hoover said
these Panthers represent the greatest threat
translation.ko: 후버는 블랙팬서가 당시 미국 민주주의의 가장 큰 위협이라고 말했어요

translation.en: to American democracy at the time.
The Panthers never were that big.
I mean, no one in their right mind could ever believe
that the Black Panthers were gonna bring down
translation.ko: 아무도 믿지 않았어요 블랙팬서가 가장 막강한 군대를

translation.en: the greatest military force in the history of the world.
translation.ko: 블랙팬서가 가장 막강한 군대를 전복할 거라고는요

translation.en: The whole movement was criminalized
and destroyed systematically by the government.
People haven't thought about what it means to lose a Fred Hampton,
translation.ko: 사람들은 프레드 햄프턴 죽음이 어떤 의미인지 모를 거예요

translation.en: who somehow was able to pull together blacks and whites and Puerto Ricans and Native Americans
to fight for justice at 21.
translation.ko: 정의를 위해 싸우도록 한 자리에 모을 수 있는 인물이었죠

translation.en: We're going to say it after this and after I'm locked up
translation.ko: 이후에도 우린 말할 겁니다 제가 구금되고 모두가 구금된 후에도

translation.en: and after everybody's locked up,
that you can jail revolutionaries, but you can't jail a revolution.
translation.ko: 혁명가는 가둬도 혁명을 가둘 순 없다고요

translation.en: He had to go.
The head of the Black Panthers in Illinois was killed today by police in Chicago.
translation.ko: 일리노이 블랙팬서의 수장이 경찰에 의해 사망했습니다

translation.en: [reporter] Illinois Panther Chairman Fred Hampton and another Panther leader
translation.ko: 일리노이 블랙팬서 수장 프레드 햄프턴과 피오리아의 또 다른 수장이 사망했습니다

translation.en: from Peoria, Illinois, were killed.
This is where our chairman had his brains blown out
translation.ko: 여기가 우리 지도자의 머리가 날아간 자리예요

translation.en: as he lay in his bed sleeping at 4:30 in the morning.
[Jones] They literally went and shot his whole house up,

So afraid of a leader that could unite people.
We know the history of folks

translation.ko: 우리는 이런 체제에 저항한 사람들의 역사를 알아요

translation.en: and we know how the system has murdered them, assassinated them,
translation.ko: 그리고 그 체제가 그들을 어떻게 살해하고 암살했는지

translation.ko: 추방하고 배척했는지 평판을 떨어뜨릴 방법을 찾았는지를요

translation.en: Assata Shakur was one of the great leaders of the Black Liberation Army.
translation.ko: 아사타 샤커는 흑인 해방군 최고의 지도자였습니다

translation.en: That, um, order given by J. Edgar Hoover
translation.ko: 존 에드거 후버는 모든 흑인 운동과 진보 운동을

translation.en: was essentially to destroy any black, progressive...
translation.ko: 존 에드거 후버는 모든 흑인 운동과 진보 운동을 말살하라고 지시했어요

translation.en: Third World movement in this country.
[Jones] They put her in prison,

translation.ko: 그녀의 동지가 말했죠 '절대 감옥에 놔두지 않아'

translation.en: Her white allies said, "We're not gonna leave her in prison."
translation.ko: 수감된 백인 동지도 말했죠 '절대 감옥에 놔두지 않아'

translation.en: And pulled her out of prison and got her to Cuba. She's in Cuba right now.
translation.ko: 그리고 그녀를 빼내 쿠바로 보냈습니다 그녀는 지금도 쿠바에 있죠

translation.en: [Shakur] And within the next five years,

translation.en: [Davis] Criminalization of Assata Shakur,

translation.ko: 언론을 이용해 샤커를 위험한 범죄자로 묘사할 거예요

What does it mean to be a criminal in this society?
translation.ko: 이 사회에서 범죄자란 뭘 의미하는 걸까요?

translation.en: That had to be broken up.
[Davis] And in my case, Ronald Reagan was the governor of California,
translation.ko: 제 경우에는 로널드 레이건이 캘리포니아 주지사였고

The whole apparatus of the state was set up against me,

The actions of the FBI in apprehending Angela Davis,
a rather remarkable, uh, story again...

Comes in, the big Afro, she didn't go press her hair.

translation.en: She was facing major time.
You know, most people, they'd have got a nice little press.
You know? They'd have been in there with little white gloves on,

translation.ko: 검찰 측에 엄청난 충격을 주고 당당히 걸어 나왔어요

Do you get there by confrontation, violence?
Oh, was that the question you were asking? [man] Yeah.
So, I grew up in Birmingham, Alabama.
Uh, after the four young girls who were... who lived very...
translation.ko: 거기 살던 소녀 네 명의 뒤를 따랐어요

I was very good friends with the sister of another one.
translation.ko: 전 다른 한 명의 자매와 아주 친했고 제 자매는 셋 모두와 친하게 지냈어요

translation.en: My sister was good friends with all three of them.
translation.ko: 제 자매는 셋 모두와 친하게 지냈어요 "교회 폭탄 폭발로 아이 넷 사망, 17명 부상"

translation.en: My mother taught one of them in her class. And they went down.
translation.ko: 그중 하나는 제 엄마의 학생이었죠 거기에서 사람들이 뭘 찾았게요?

translation.en: And what did they find? They found limbs and heads just strewn all over the place.
translation.ko: 거기에서 사람들이 뭘 찾았게요? 여기저기 굴러다니는 팔과 머리였어요

translation.en: I remember, from the time I was very small,
I remember the sounds of bombs exploding across the street.
translation.ko: 길 건너에서 폭탄이 터지는 소리를 기억해요

translation.en: Our house shaking.
I remember my father having to have guns at his disposal at all times
translation.ko: 아빠가 총을 휴대하신 것도 생각나요 언제든 쓸 수 있게요

translation.en: because of the fact that at any moment we might expect to be attacked.
I mean, that's why, when someone asks me about violence, uh...
translation.ko: 그래서 누군가 제게 폭력에 관해 물으면

translation.en: I just, uh... I just find it incredible.
Because what it means is that the person who's asking that question
translation.ko: 그런 질문을 하는 사람은 흑인이 어떤 걸 겪는지

translation.en: has absolutely no idea what black people have gone through,
what black people have experienced in this country

translation.ko: 처음 아프리카 해안에서 이곳으로 납치당한 후로요

translation.en: [Jones] And when you strip out a whole generation of leadership,

translation.en: you will be vulnerable to Bill Clinton or anybody else.
translation.ko: 빌 클린턴 같은 적에게 취약해지게 되겠죠

translation.en: They'll do to you what they will.
translation.ko: 그러면 놈들은 당신을 멋대로 주무를 겁니다

translation.en: ♪ There's a man going 'round ♪

♪ He has taken my father's name ♪

♪ There's a man going 'round ♪
♪ Taking names ♪
♪ Going 'round ♪
♪ Going 'round ♪
[reporter] An armed neighborhood watch leader

translation.ko: 올랜도 근처의 한 동네로 마틴이 들어오는 걸 봤습니다

translation.en: He thought the 17-year-old looked suspicious.
[George Zimmerman] He's got his hand in his waistband.
And he's a black male.
[sighs] These assholes, they always get away.
-[dispatcher 1] Are you following him? -Yep.
-[dispatcher 1] We don't need you to. -[indistinct screaming]
[dispatcher 2] Do you think he's yelling "help"?
-[woman] Yes. -All right, what is your...
translation.ko: - 살려 달란 고함인가요? - 네 그 사람이 뭘...

translation.en: [reporter] A deadly shooting in Sanford.
translation.ko: 오늘 밤 샌퍼드에서 총기 사망 사건이 있었습니다

translation.en: Police have the gun, they've got the shooter,
but they have not arrested him.
[Stevenson] Zimmerman, armed with a gun,
followed this quote, unquote suspicious kid
after the dispatcher told him not to.
They ended up on the ground in a fight,

translation.ko: 조지 지머맨은 트레이번 마틴을 총으로 쏴 살해했습니다

translation.en: The police could not arrest Zimmerman
because of this Florida law called Stand Your Ground,
which says that you can kill someone if you feel threatened.
translation.ko: 위험하다고 생각되면 누군가 죽일 수 있죠

translation.en: Even though it was Zimmerman
who had pursued Martin throughout the neighborhood with a gun.
Mr. Zimmerman felt that he, in self-defense, needed to, uh...
translation.ko: 지머맨 씨는 총을 쏴서 자신을 방어해야겠다고 느꼈습니다

translation.en: to fire his weapon.
[Stevenson] Not only was he not arrested,
translation.ko: 그는 살인을 하고도 체포되지 않았을 뿐만 아니라

translation.en: but in court, Zimmerman actually pleaded self-defense
and got off under the Stand Your Ground law.
[woman] We, the jury, find George Zimmerman not guilty.
[man] That Stand Your Ground law that was passed in Florida
played a huge role in the Trayvon Martin tragedy
and this really ignited the movement that we see today.
[reporter] In the wake of Trayvon Martin's death,
Florida's Stand Your Ground law came into the spotlight.
How did this law not only get in place in Florida, but around the country?
translation.ko: 어떻게 이 법이 플로리다뿐 아니라 "라샤드 로빈슨 컬러 오브 체인지" 곳곳에서 적용될 수 있죠?

translation.en: And all the fingers kept pointing back to ALEC.
ALEC sounds like the name of a high school lacrosse player
translation.ko: "알렉 미국입법교류회의" 알렉은 고등학교 시절 아빠 차를 막 박살 낸

translation.en: who just got baked and wrecked his dad's Saab.
But incredibly, it's actually even worse.
-ALEC is a political lobbying group. -[all] ALEC is a political lobbying group.
translation.ko: 알렉은 정치적 로비 집단이다 알렉은 정치적 로비 집단이다

translation.en: -They write laws... -They write laws...
-and give them to Republicans. -and give them to Republicans.
-Stand Your Ground... -Stand Your Ground...
-was written by ALEC. -was written by ALEC.
[Graves] ALEC is this private club,
and its members are politicians and corporations.
But the real question is,
should politicians and corporations be in the same private club?
translation.ko: 정치인과 기업인이 같은 단체에 있어도 될까요?

translation.en: Under the umbrella of ALEC
corporate members, uh, get to propose laws to their political counterparts,
most of whom are Republicans.
So, through ALEC, corporations have a huge say in our lawmaking.
translation.ko: 알렉을 통해 기업은 입법에 막대한 발언권을 얻죠

translation.en: And at ALEC task force meetings,
corporate lobbyists secretly vote as equals with lawmakers
translation.ko: 기업 로비스트는 비밀스럽게 똑같이 투표합니다 입법자와 함께하죠

translation.en: on bills that those lawmakers then introduce
translation.ko: 입법자와 함께하죠 그렇게 입법자는 법안을 발의합니다

translation.en: to become laws in our states.
translation.ko: 그렇게 입법자는 법안을 발의합니다 "입법자는 법안을 발의한다"

translation.en: ALEC is everywhere.
Roughly one in four state legislators are members.
translation.ko: 대략 의원 넷 중 하나가 회원입니다

translation.en: And I'm proud to stand with ALEC today.
And it's not hard to see why. ALEC makes their jobs troublingly easy.
translation.ko: 이유는 간단합니다 알렉이 일을 쉽게 해주거든요

translation.en: Here's their model Electricity Freedom bill,

translation.ko: 이런 조항이 있군요 '제정되게 할 것 무슨 무슨 주에서'

translation.ko: '제정되게 할 것 무슨 무슨 주에서' '재생 가능 에너지 조항을 삭제하게 할 것'

translation.en: So, as long as you can remember and spell the name of your state,
translation.ko: 살고 있는 주 이름의 철자만 제대로 쓸 수 있으면

translation.en: you can introduce legislation.
We've also seen ALEC bills introduced
translation.ko: 우리는 알렉의 법안이 발의되는 걸 목격했어요

translation.en: where a lawmaker forgot to take the ALEC letterhead off the bill.
Without remembering to take off the ALEC letterhead
to try to distance the real role of ALEC and ALEC corporations from those bills.
I'm just curious. Does it have...
Does the legislation have some connection to ALEC?
Representative Atkins, I'm not sure why we're pursuing this course of questioning.
translation.ko: 앳킨스 의원님 왜 그런 질문을 하시죠? "스티브 갓월트 미네소타 주 대표"

translation.en: This bill is my bill. It's not ALEC's bill.
The reason I ask is because earlier you passed out a handout
translation.ko: 제가 묻는 이유는 앞서 나눠주신 유인물에

translation.en: that says "Gottwalt" at the top, and it says "Health Care Compact,"

And I went to the ALEC website,

translation.ko: 같은 글자, 같은 크기의 같은 로고가 있더군요

translation.en: I mean, literally, it's verbatim.
[Graves] It's shocking to know
that ALEC has been around for more than four decades now.
translation.ko: 놀라운 사실은 알렉이 40년 넘게 있었다는 사실입니다

translation.en: And it's even more startling to see how it began.
[Reagan] ALEC has forged a unique partnership
between state legislators and leaders from the corporate and business community.
translation.ko: 알렉은 의원과 기업의 수뇌부 사이에 독특한 동업 관계를 구축했습니다

translation.en: we wouldn't be talking about two million people behind bars today.
translation.ko: 지금 우리는 감옥에 있는 2백만 명의 사람들에 대해 얘기하지 않았을 거예요

translation.en: People say all the time,
"I don't understand how people could've tolerated slavery.
How could they have made peace with that?
How could people have gone to a lynching and participated in that?
How did people make sense of the segregation,
this white and colored-only drinking... That's so crazy.
If I was living at that time, I would have never tolerated anything like that."
translation.ko: '내가 그 시대에 살고 있다면' '난 절대 그냥 넘기지 않아'

translation.en: And the truth is, we are living at this time, and we are tolerating it.
translation.ko: 하지만 사실은 지금 이 시대에도 우린 여전히 용인하고 있습니다
